Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Applying a Social Ecological Framework to Inmate Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Racial and ethnic disparities in health status and health care are a major concern for both scientists and public health officials. To date, very little research has focused on the role of mass incarceration on future trends of health disparities. Research reveals disparities in health for inmates across multiple domains, including chronic health and infectious diseases, serious mental illness, and substance use disorders. Yet, incarceration is an often ignored and poorly understood factor in health disparities research, in general. Incarcerated persons are excluded from national health surveys and correctional facilities often have an inadequate surveillance system for providing valid and reliable data on inmate health status. Understanding the health profile and health care needs of the incarcerated population is imperative for achieving health equity and understanding and maintaining the public health of the local communities from which inmates are drawn.

The proposed dissertation uses an epidemiological criminology perspective in conjunction with large and representative national data sets to examine the factors that contribute to mortality, morbidity, and health service utilization among an often neglected yet increasingly relevant group for population health: incarcerated adults.

Understanding how mass incarceration influences population health and health disparities is imperative for health care policy. Prisons are currently uniquely situated to provide healthcare to individuals who are likely underserved in their communities. Understanding the health care needs of this population is especially timely and given the overrepresentation of racial and ethnic minorities in U.S. prisons, providing diagnosis and effective treatment during incarceration as well as providing for transitions in care upon release may help reduce health disparities in the population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world, but the rate of incarceration varies by gender and race/ethnicity. That is, some groups are impacted more by the U.S. system of mass incarceration than others. Black men have the highest rate of incarceration, by far. Black men are incarcerated at a rate 2.5 times that of Latino men and almost 6 times that of white men. Similarly, black women are incarcerated at a rate twice that of white and Latina women. It is important to note that social science research finds that the differences in incarceration rates are not due to differences in participation in criminal behaviors but differences in surveillance, policing, and sentencing. Race/ethnic inequalities in health status and health care are also a major concern. For example, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has as their goal for 2020 to achieve health equity, eliminate disparities, and improve the health of all groups. With approximately 650,000 people leaving prisons and 11.1 million people being cycled through jails every year, it is important to understand the factors that contribute to health problems for inmates and how mass incarceration influences the health of the population including race/ethnic inequalities in health and healthcare. Yet, incarceration is an often ignored and poorly understood factor in health disparities research, in general.

 

This project incorporated multiple national data sets and analytical approaches to examine inequalities for inmates in mortality, morbidity, and health service utilization. This project found 1) distinct patterns of inequality in health and mortality among the incarcerated population; 2) inequalities in who accesses health services in prison despite the fact that inmates have a constitutional right to adequate care while incarcerated; and 3) imprisonment has a lasting negative impact on health and the use of health services (including health insurance coverage, regular emergency department use, and not have regular check-ups) once inmates are released back to their communities that isn’t accounted for by unemployment. These findings are important because if left untreated, health conditions can result in repeated cycling through the correctional system, exacerbation of disease, and avoidable and expensive hospitalizations and emergency room visits. Given the overrepresentation of racial and ethnic minorities in U.S. prisons, providing diagnosis and effective treatment during incarceration as well as providing for transitions in care upon release may help to achieve health equity.
